text: The Magic Bowl
There once was a girl named Nandita who was very poor.
One day, she took her last piece of bread to the temple of the goddess Parvati.
"Parvati, this bread is for you," she said.
Suddenly, the statue began to glow, and then the real Parvati appeared!
"You're very generous," said Parvati.
"I want to reward you."
"Parvati," said Nandita,
"I'm very hungry, and so are my neighbors."
Parvati held out a wooden bowl.
"Take this magic bowl," she said.
"What will it do?" asked Nandita.
"It will give you any food you ask for," said Parvati.
"Try it!"
"I...I want some...creamy pudding," Nandita said.
POP! The magic bowl filled with creamy pudding.
"Wow! Thank you," said Nandita.
Nandita took the bowl home.
Every day, she held a huge feast for all her neighbors.
"Thank you for the food I" said an old woman.
"You're welcome," said Nandita.
One day, the evil king and his advisor came to the village and saw the great feast.
"Girl, where did you get all this food?" the king asked Nandita.
"I have a magic bowl, sir," she answered.
"A magic bowl?" asked the advisor.
"Are you lying to the king?"
"No, your highness!" said Nandita.
"Ask for any food."
After a moment, the king said, "I want... lamb curry with saffron."
POP! The food appeared.
The king and his advisor were shocked.
'Sir," the advisor said, "this bowl is meant for a king."
"Yes ... yes, you're right," said the king.
"Give me the bowl, girl!"
Nandita had no choice.
"Yes, sir," she said, and handed him the bowl.
The king took the bowl to his palace.
He sat down to dinner that night at the royal table.
"I want... mangoes!" he told the bowl.
POP!
Giant, slimy slugs filled the bowl.
"Ugh!"
"Let me try, sir," said his advisor.
"I want some ... crispy samosas!" he declared.
POP!
Creepy crawly cockroaches ran out of the bowl.
"Ack!" he yelled.
Right away, the king ordered Nandita to come to the palace.
"This bowl doesn't work," he told her.
"Fix it, or die," said the advisor.
"But, your highness, I don't know how!" she said.
"You have one day," the king said coldly.
That night, Nandita went back to Parvati.
"Parvati, the king took the magic bowl," she said
"It didn't work for him, did it?" asked Parvati.
"No, it didn,t"
"What did he say?" asked Parvati.
"He told me to fix it  or...or die," Nandita said, crying.
"Take this magic stick," Parvati said with a sly smile.
"It'll help you get the bowl back."
Nandita took the stick and went back to the palace.
"Sir," she said to the king,
"this magic stick might help you."
"Give it to me," said the king, snatching the stick.
He hit the bowl with it.
At that moment, the stick leaped into the air and began to hit the king and his advisor!
WHACK! WHACK!
"Ow! Ouch!" they cried.
"Make it stopl"
"It'll stop if you give the bowl back," said Nandita.
"No!" said the advisor.
The stick hit them harder.
WHACK! WHACK!
"Fine! Take it!" yelled the king.
Immediately, the stick stopped.
"Now leavel'' ordered the king.
Nandita wasted no time.
She took the bowl and the stick, and she ran home.
From then on, Nandita and her neighbors lived in peace and never went hungry again.
